1 Journal of Molecular Catalysis, 74 (1992) 379-390 379 M2928 Si02-supported bimetallic ruthenium cluster-derived catalysts for selectivity and activity control in CO hydrogenation toward C1-C5 alcohols Feng-Shou Xiao* Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 060 (Japan) and Department of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130023 (China) Atsushi Fukuoka, Masaru Ichikawa* Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 060 (Japan) W. Henderson and D. F. Shriver Department of Chemistry, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208-3113 (USA) Abstract The bimetallic RUC03, RuC02 and Ru3M,C (M=Co, Fe, Ni, Mo, Rh, Cr, Mn, x=1-3) catalysts were prepared from S'02-supported carbonyl clusters, and it was found that the RuCo, RuFe and RuMo bimetallic carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts showed higher activity and selectivity for oxygenates such as C,-C5 alcohols in CO hydrogenation. In contrast, hydrocarbons and COz were preferentially obtained on the catalysts prepared from Si02-SUPPorted homometallic RueC, Ru3 and Cog carbonyl clusters. The RuNi, RuCr, RuMn and RuRh carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts provided poor activity and selectivity for oxygenates. The promotion toward alcohol formation on RuCo, RuFe and RuMo cluster-derived catalysts was proposed to be associated with the adjacent Ru-M" (M=Co, Fe, and Mo) at the cluster-oxide support interface to offer C- and O-ended CO (v(CO) = 1680 cm-'). In situ FT-IR studies revealed that the band at 1584 cm-', possibly assigned to a formyl intermediate on RuM (M = Co, Fe, and Mo) bimetallic cluster-derived catalysts at 453 K under syngas (CO/HZ=0.5), has a good linear relationship with the rate of oxygenate formation, whereas the 1584 cm-' band was not observed on Rumn, RuCr, RuRh and RuNi bimetallic and homometallic cluster-derived catalysts showing poor activity for oxygenates. At higher temperatures the higher alcohols (C-C5) are produced via CO dissociation and acetyl intermediate (v(CO)=1555 cm-') formation from CO +HZ on the RuCo cluster-derived catalysts. Introduction Chemical modification of solid surfaces, e.g., Si02, A1203, MgO and zeolites, using organometallic carbonyl clusters as the precursors is a subject of recent interest. This approach may make possible the rational preparation of tailored metal catalysts involving the well-characterized metal centers. Thus they may provide some advantages in obtaining highly dispersed metal *Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/92/$5.00 1992 - Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved 380 particles with a uniform size distribution and with a discrete metal composition of the precursor bimetallic clusters. The specific metal/bimetal structures derived from the surface-grafted metal cluster are reflected in modifying the catalytic performances in CO hydrogenation to offer higher selectivities and activities, compared with the conventional catalysts prepared by co-impregnation and ion-exchange of metal salts [1-4]. In CO hydrogenation, one of the most important problems is the selectivity for various products, because it is well known that the order of economic interest is: higher oxygenates > methanol > hydrocarbons [51. It has previously been reported that some electropositive ions such as Mn, Ti, Zr, Nb and Fe promote the production of oxygenates such as aldehydes and alcohols in CO hydrogenation catalyzed on Rh and Pd [6-81. As a localized model for the promoters Rh and Pd, tailored metal catalysts have been prepared from Si02-supported RhFe [9-101 and PdFe [ 11 ] bimetallic carbonyl clusters as the precursors, and it has been demonstrated that they provide higher activities and improved selectivities for C1 and CZ alcohols from CO + H2, compared with those from the homometallic cluster-derived catalysts and even the conventional bimetallic catalysts. The conversion of CO + HZ to hydrocarbons and oxygenates occurs readily on Ru catalyst or bimetallic catalysts based on Ru, such as RuCu, RuAg and RuFe [ 12-14 ]. In this study, we prepared a series of RuM (M = Co, Fe, Mo, Ni, Rh, Cr, Mn) bimetallic catalysts using mixed-bimetallic ruthenium carbonyl clusters impregnated with Si02, and studied the activity and selectivity for product in CO hydrogenation over various RuM bimetallic cluster-derived catalysts. The origin of promotion for C1-C5 alcohol formation in CO hydrogenation is discussed in terms of the two-site activation of CO to produce the oxygenate intermediate formed on the adjacent RuCo sites derived from the Si02-supported clusters. Experimental Preparation of catalysts Syntheses of clusters and their depositions onto Si02 were carried out under an atmosphere of purified nitrogen using standard Schlenk and needle stock techniques [ 15 ]. Solvents were stored under Nz after being refluxed with and distilled from appropriate drying agents (acetone: 4A molecular sieves). Amorphous silica (surface area 280 cm' g-1, Davison no. 57, 14-20 mesh) was used as a support for catalytic reactions. The Si02 was heated at 573 K under vacuum for 4 h and stored under N2 in a dry-box. The carbonyl clusters used in this work and references for their syntheses [ 16-18 ] are listed in Table 1. Co4(CO)12 was purchased from Strem and purified by recrystallization from pentane. In a typical run, Ru3Co3C(CO)14 was dissolved in 30 ml of acetone, and Si02 was added to the solution under N2. After 30 min of stirring, the sample was carefully evacuated to remove acetone at room temperature, followed by calcination in OZ flow (1 bar, 40 ml min-1) at 423 K for 2 h in a glass tube, and reduced by the reaction in Hz flow 381 TABLE 1 Preparation of Ru monometallic and Ru-M (M=Co, Fe, Mo, Ni, Rh, Cr and Mn) bimetallic carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts Precursor Ref. Weight Sioz Ru loading (mg) (g) [Et9N][HRu3(CO) ] 17 73(210) 3.0 1.0(3.0) Ru6C(CO),7 16 58(170) 2.0 1.0(3.0) Ru3Co3C(CO)14 18 29(87) 1.0 1.0(3.0) RuCo2(C0)11 18 53(157) 1.0 1.0(3.0) HRuCo3(CO),2 18 61(180) 1.0 1.0(3.0) [Et9N12 [Ru3Fe3C(CO)131 16 37(109) 1.0 1.0(3.0) [Et9N12[Ru3Mo2C(CO)16] 16 41(120) 1.0 1.0(3.0) [Et4N]Z[Ru3Rh3C(CO)15] 16 43(125) 1.0 1.0(3.0) [Et4N]Z[Ru3MnC(CO)14] 16 34(101) 1.0 1.0(3.0) [PPN]2[Ru3Cr2C(CO),61 16 64(192) 1.0 1.0(3.0) (1 bar, 40 ml min-') at the programmed temperature from 293 to 573 K for 2 h and at 573 K for 2 h. The sample was transferred to a microreactor and reduced again in H2 flow at 573 K for 1 h prior to introducing syngas. CO hydrogenation The CO hydrogenation reaction was carried out using a stainless-steel reactor, into which 1.0 g of the catalyst (Ru loading 1 wt.%) was charged. A mixture of CO and Hz (CO/H2=0.5 and 1.0, 5 bar) was introduced into the reactor at a flow rate of 40 ml min-' and a space velocity of 444 h-'. Oxygenates, including alcohols and aldehydes, were collected in 50 ml of water trapping by bubbling the effluent gas through it. The products were analyzed by the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and flame ionisation detector (FID) of a gas chromatograph using active carbon, alumina-N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF 38%, 60-80 mesh), and Squalane columns for CO and COz, hydrocarbons, and oxygenates, respectively. Infrared experiments The catalysts (Ru loading 3 wt.%) were pressed into self-supporting disks (15 mm i.d., 12 mg cm-2) and were placed into an infrared cell equipped with CaFz windows. Infrared spectra were measured at various conditions using a Fourier transform spectrometer (Shimadzu FT-4100) with a resolution of 2 cm-'. For the isotope-labelling experiments 13C0 (9Oss6 enriched) and D2 (99.99ss'o) were purchased from MSD Isotope. Results and discussion RuM bimetallic cluster-derived catalysts in CO hydrogenation The catalytic activity of Si02-supported RuM carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts reached the steady state of CO conversion and product selectivities 382 orienting toward alcohols after 10-15 h on stream in CO hydrogenation, and remained constant for a subsequent 45-50 h. Catalytic performances for various products, including hydrocarbons, oxygenates and C02, in CO hydrogenation at 519 K are presented in Table 2, where the selectivities were based on CO. The Ru3/Si02 catalyst prepared from an anion cluster [HRu3(CO)11]- provided CO conversion at 0.3296, and products consisted uniquely of hydrocarbons (over 991Yo). Compared with Ru3/Si02, Rus/Si02 prepared from RuBC(CO),7 exhibited high rates for hydrocarbon formation (conversion 4.9%) with poor selectivity of oxygenates (290 selectivity in CO base). These results demonstrate that the carbide species contained in Ru6C(CO)17 is a very important precursor for producing hydrocarbons in CO hydrogenation, which is consistent with other work [19-22]. In contrast to Ru6C(CO)17, the catalysts from RuM (M = Co, Fe, Mo, Ni, Rh, Cr and Mn) mixed-bimetallic carbonyl clusters impregnated on Si02 exhibited the following features: (i) the activities for both hydrocarbons and oxygenates on RuCo bimetallic catalysts prepared from Ru3Co3C(CO)14, RuCo2(CO)11 and HRuC03(CO)12 increased greatly, in particular for oxygenates; (ii) the CO conversion on RuFe and RuMo bimetallic catalysts decreased considerably, but the activity for oxygenates increased greatly; as a result, the selectivities for oxygenates consisting of methanol and ethanol in CO hydrogenation were up to 28 and 269'0 over those of RuFe and RuMo catalysts, respectively; (iii) RuNi and RuRh catalysts prepared from [Ru3Ni3C(CO)13]2- and [Ru3Rh3C(CO)15]2- clusters provided lower CO conversion (0.46 and 0.47%) than RU6/Si06; the rates of oxygenate formation were similar to that on Rub/ Si02, but the hydrocarbons were greatly suppressed; (iv) the promoters such as Mn and Cr in RuMn and RuCr catalysts prepared from [Ru3MnC(CO)14]2and [Ru3Cr2C(CO)16]2- led to a deep decrease in activities for both hydrocarbons and oxygenates, although the selectivity for oxygenates remained in the range 12-209'0. The above results indicate that the RuCo, RuFe and RuMo bimetallic catalysts are among the best catalysts for formation of oxygenated products, especially for the RuCo bimetallic catalyst, which exhibited higher selectivity for higher oxygenates (C2-C5). However, some electropositive ions such as Mn and Cr cannot promote the production of oxygenates on RuM (M = Mn and Cr) carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts, although it has been reported that these electropositive ions remarkably promoted formation of oxygenates on Rh and Pd catalysts [6-11 ] in CO hydrogenation. These results can be explained by differences in behavior such as reduction, adsorption, CO dissociation, CO insertion, etc. under syngas between Ru-based and Rh- or Pd-based catalysts. The use of CO-rich syngas in CO hydrogenation resulted in a considerable decrease in CO conversion and a marked increase in oxygenated selectivity on various RuM bimetallic carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts. For instance, when the CO/H2 ratio over the HRuC03(CO)12 carbonyl cluster-derived catalyst, changed from 0.5 to 1.0, CO conversion was quickly reduced from 4.7 to 2.290, and the rate of hydrocarbon formation greatly decreased while the rate of oxygenate formation greatly increased. W 00 W 384 selectivity for oxygenates in total products increased with the molar ratio of CO/H2, which is very significant for the selective production of oxygenates in conversion of syngas and synthesis of other chemicals in industrial processes. In situ FT-IR studies IR characterization of various catalysts under syngas was investigated using FT-IR. After the sample disk was reduced by hydrogen at 573 K for 2 h, syngas (molar ratio CO/H2 =1/2) was passed through the sample wafer at a flow rate of 40 ml min-1 for 15 h at 453 K. After evacuation for 20 min at room temperature to remove physical or weak chemical adsorption of CO and H2, the spectrum of Ru6/Si02 catalyst prepared from Ru6C(CO)17 exhibited broad bands at 2060 and 1880 cm-1 and weak bands at 2932 and 2860 cm-1. The bands at 2060 and 1880 cm-1 are assigned to the CO linear and bridging adsorption, respectively, on the Ru surface [23-25], and those at 2930 and 2860 cm-1 are attributed to the C-H stretching frequencies [23]. As typical examples, Fig. 1 shows the IR spectra of syngas reacted with RuCo, RuFe and RuMn carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts. On the RuCo, RuFe and RuMo bimetallic carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts providing high rates for oxygenates, the sample spectra show a new band at 1584 cm-1 in addition to the bands that appeared in Rue,/Si02- On the other hand, the 2046 1564 1680 1375 2930 2054 a 2660 0 a o a 2926 V 2972 2656 2p56 1584 1460 123 79b 2932 C 3000 2000 1500 Wavenumber WK-1) Fig. 1. IR spectra in CO chemisorption at 300-340 K on Ru3Co3C(CO),4/Si02 after HZ reduction for 2 h at 573 K. 386 band at 1584 cm-' was not observed on the RuNi, RuRh, RuMn and RuCr bimetallic catalysts showing poor activity for oxygenates. Table 3 summarizes the intensities of the infrared bands at 2060, 1880 and 1584 cm-' and the rate of oxygenate formation over RuM bimetallic carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts. There was a good linear relationship between the rate of oxygenate formation and the intensity of the 1584 cm-' band. However, there were no correlations between the 2050 and 1880 cm-' band intensities and rates of oxygenate formation. These results indicate that the species giving rise to the band at 1584 cm-' plays an important role in the production of oxygenates, and is probably an intermediate in the formation of oxygenates in CO hydrogenation. When CO was adsorbed on catalysts such as Ru3Co3C/SiO2 and RuCo3/ Si02, sample spectra exhibited a new band at 1680 cm-', which shifted to 1640 cm-' with 13C0 due to the '3C0 isotope effect, as shown in Fig. 2. When catalysts such as RuCo were exposed to various gases (CO or '3C0/ HZ or DZ = 0.5) such as '3C0 + Hz, CO + DZ and '3C0 + D2, the 1584 cm-' band formed in the gases of CO and HZ shifted to 1542, 1575 and 1539 cm-', respectively, as shown in Fig. 3. Proposed mechanism for methanol and CZ-C5 alcohol formation in CO hydrogenation on the RuCo adjacent sites. that the band at 1584 cm-' could be assigned to the C=O stretching frequency of formyl [:HC=O], which results from hydrogenation of the Cand O-ended CO on the adjacent RuCo sites, as shown in Fig. 4. Some analogous IR bands due to formyl coordination have been reported in Os(CHO)(H)(COz)(PPh3) (v(CO) = 1601, v(C-H) = 2760 cm-'), Re(Et)(CO)(NO)(CHO) (v(CO) = 1624 cm-') and Li+(CO)5ReRe(CO)(CHO) (v(CO)=1529 cm-') [26]. The C-H band of the CHO species is too weak to be detected by IR. Horwitz and Shriver [27] demonstrated that the stoichiometric formation of adducts between metal carbonyls such as Fe2(CO)9 and Ru3(CO), 2 and Lewis acids such as AIC13 and BF3 arises from C- and O-bound CO characteristic of bands at 1740-1520 cm-'. Moreover, the adsorption of model compounds such as paraformaldehyde and methanol also exhibited bands at 1584 cm-' at room temperature and 453 K. It has been reported that a low-frequency band of CO occurred on conventional RhMn, RhTi and RhZr/Si02 [ 6-12 ], which are active for oxygenate formation in CO hydrogenation, where a large reduction of the CO frequency (1730-1620 cm-') was induced. By comparing the FT-IR data with the structural model of the bimetallic cluster-derived catalysts, it is conceivable that the RuM 388 a) background Cat: HRuCo3(CO)121Si02 10- Torr CO+H2(1:2) Iatm,473K,2h after evacuation ,I. . 10 12 14 16 18 20 125 27 29 31 33 35 b) Reaction with H2 at 473K, 30 min ,11111 10 12 14 16 18 20 25 27 29 31 33 35 c) Reaction with D2 at 473 K, 30 min . I ~ 1 ~ I I I 10 12 14 16 18 20 ~25 27 29 31 33 35 Mass number (cm 1) Fig. 5. Mass analysis of products formed in the reaction of surface species in CO +HZ reaction with HZ or DZ at 473 K for 30 min. (M = Co, Fe and Mo) sites in the catalysts gave two-site CO activation on similar [Ru-C=O-M]. After the reaction of syngas (CO + HZ) with reduced RuCo carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts for 16 h at 453 K, the band at 1584 cm-' appeared, which is proposed to be due to formyl species. When 100 torr of HZ or DZ was introduced into the IR cell, the intensity of the 1584 cm-' band decreased with reaction time, while the 3020 cm-' band and the 2928 and 2258 cm-' bands increased gradually in the IR spectra, which are assigned to CH4 and CHD3, respectively. On the other hand, at the same time mass analysis of the gas phase (Fig. 5) exhibited two mass-number regions at 13-16 and 29-32 and two regions at 15-19 and 30-35 for reaction of the proposed formyl species with HZ and with D2, respectively, suggesting that the formyl species formed in CO + H2 is converted with H2 (D2) mainly to CH4 + CH3OH (CHD3 + CHD2OD). At temperatures above 473 K the yields of higher C2+ alcohols substantially increased in the CO + HZ reaction on various RuCo catalysts, as shown in Table 2. It is interesting to note from the IR study that the band at 1584 cm-' decreased gradually and a new band at 1555 cm-' developed in time-on-stream (Fig. 3(e)), where CZ-C5 alcohols were detected in the gas phase by GC-MS. These results suggest that the twosite CO activation on the RuCo sites resulted in CO dissociation at higher temperatures to form alkyls, which underwent further insertion with CO to make higher-carbon oxygenates such as CZ-C5 alcohols in CO hydrogenation on the RuCo catalysts, as proposed in the mechanism in Fig. 4. 389 Conclusion It has been demonstrated that the RuCo, RuFe and RuMo bimetallic carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts show high activity and selectivity for oxygenates, compared with the catalysts prepared from impregnation of monometallic clusters such as Ru6C(CO)17. For the RuNi and RuRh catalysts, they provide similar activity for oxygenates to Ru6C(CO)17/SiO2, but the selectivity markedly increases owing to suppression of hydrocarbons. The promoters such as Mn and Cr in RuMn and RuCr catalysts lead to a great decrease in oxygenate amount, in contrast to Ru6/Si02 catalyst. In situ FT-IR studies demonstrate that the band at 1584 cm-1 on RuM (M= Co, Fe, Mo) bimetallic cluster-derived catalyst is linearly related to the rates of oxygenate formation; the band is likely due to an intermediate in the production of oxygenates in CO hydrogenation. The isotope study and analysis of mass spectroscopy suggested that the 1584 cm-1 band can be assigned to a `surface formyl' group. The promotion toward alcohol formation on RuCo, RuFe and RuMo cluster-derived catalysts was proposed to be associated with the adjacent Ru-M5' (M= Co, Fe and Mo) at the cluster-oxide support interface to offer C- and O-ended CO (P(CO) = 1680 cm-1). At higher temperatures the higher C2-C5 alcohols are produced via CO dissociation and acetyl intermediate (P(CO)=1555 cm-') formation from CO+HZ on the RuCo cluster-derived catalysts. X244 9280255F 0304-5102(92)80255-F 10.1016/0304-5102(92)80255-F Elsevier Sequoia SiO2-supported bimetallic ruthenium cluster-derived catalysts for selectivity and activity control in CO hydrogenation toward C1 C5 alcohols Feng-Shou Xiao * Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University, Sapporro 060 Japan Department of Chemistry, Jilin University, Changchun 130023 China * Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed. Atsushi Fukuoka Masaru Ichikawa * Catalysis Research Center, Hokkaido University, Sapporo 060 Japan * Authors to whom correspondence should be addressed. W. Henderson D.F. Shriver Department of Chemistry, Northwestern University, Evanston, IL 60208-3113 USA The bimetallic RuCo3, RuCo2 and Ru3M x C (M = Co, Fe, Ni, Mo, Rh, Cr, Mn,x=1–3) catalysts were prepared from SiO2-supported carbonyl clusters, and it was found that the RuCo, RuFe and RuMo bimetallic carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts showed higher activity and selectivity for oxygenates such as C1 C5 alcohols in CO hydrogenation. In contrast, hydrocarbons and CO2 were preferentially obtained on the catalysts prepared from SiO2-supported homometallic Ru6C, Ru3 and Co4 carbonyl clusters. The RuNi, RuCr, RuMn and RuRh carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts provided poor activity and selectivity for oxygenates. The promotion toward alcohol formation on RuCo, RuFe and RuMo cluster-derived catalysts was proposed to be associated with the adjacent Ru-Mδ+ (M = Co, Fe, and Mo) at the cluster—oxide support interface to offer C- and O-ended CO (v(CO) = 1680 cm−1).In situ FT—IR studies revealed that the band at 1584 cm−1, possibly assigned to a formyl intermediate on RuM (M = Co, Fe, and Mo) bimetallic cluster-derived catalysts at 453 K under syngas (CO/H2=0.5), has a good linear relationship with the rate of oxygenate formation, whereas the 1584 cm−1 band was not observed on RuMn, RuCr, RuRh and RuNi bimetallic and homometallic cluster-derived catalysts showing poor activity for oxygenates. At higher temperatures the higher alcohols (C2 C5) are produced via CO dissociation and acetyl intermediate (v(CO) = 1555 cm1¯) formation from CO+H2 on the RuCo cluster-derived catalysts. In contrast, hydrocarbons and CO2 were preferentially obtained on the catalysts prepared from SiO2-supported homometallic Ru6C, Ru3 and Co4 carbonyl clusters. The RuNi, RuCr, RuMn and RuRh carbonyl cluster-derived catalysts provided poor activity and selectivity for oxygenates. The promotion toward alcohol formation on RuCo, RuFe and RuMo cluster-derived catalysts was proposed to be associated with the adjacent Ru-Mδ+ (M = Co, Fe, and Mo) at the cluster—oxide support interface to offer C- and O-ended CO (v(CO) = 1680 cm−1).In situ FT—IR studies revealed that the band at 1584 cm−1, possibly assigned to a formyl intermediate on RuM (M = Co, Fe, and Mo) bimetallic cluster-derived catalysts at 453 K under syngas (CO/H2=0.5), has a good linear relationship with the rate of oxygenate formation, whereas the 1584 cm−1 band was not observed on RuMn, RuCr, RuRh and RuNi bimetallic and homometallic cluster-derived catalysts showing poor activity for oxygenates. coredata.dc:title: SiO2-supported bimetallic ruthenium cluster-derived catalysts for selectivity and activity control in CO hydrogenation toward C1 C5 alcohols
